title: Couple get death threats after 'charging customer for cancelling cleaning appointment when she suffered miscarriage'
text:
News Couple get death threats after 'charging customer for cancelling cleaning appointment when she suffered miscarriage' Husband and wife Ben and Vicki Harbour say they have received hundreds of abusive messages after Dean and Charlotte Coutts alleged that they asked for money Share Dean and Charlotte Coutts were left devastated after losing what would have been their first baby (Photo: Dean Coutts / SWNS.com) Share Get daily   
A couple say they have received death threats and face going bust after being accused of charging a customer for a missed appointment when she suffered a miscarriage . 
Husband and wife Ben and Vicki Harbour say they have received hundreds of abusive messages after Dean and Charlotte Coutts alleged that they asked for money. 
Mr Harbour says they risk losing everything – including their home - and claims he has been compared to Jimmy Saville . 
Mr Harbour, aged 35, told the Plymouth Herald that although he is sorry, he said the whole situation has been "blown out of proportion". 
"We do want to apologise for the way it was handled," he said, "but we don't deserve what has happened to us." 
"We are being made to feel like we are criminals – that we are Plymouth's most wanted." 
Distressed Dean and Charlotte Coutts booked a session with Clean Carpets Plymouth but called it off when she was rushed to hospital. Distressed Dean and Charlotte Coutts booked a session with Clean Carpets Plymouth but called it off when she was rushed to hospital (Photo: Dean Coutts / SWNS.com) The Coutts say two weeks after losing what would have been their first child they were stunned to receive an £85 invoice for the job (Photo: SWNS.com) 
Two weeks after losing what would have been their first child they say they were stunned to receive an £85 invoice for the job - but refused to pay. 
Mr Harbour insists no invoice was ever issued. 
They claim they were then subjected to a string of "aggressive" messages demanding more money. Read More "You deserved to lose your baby": Sick message 'sent to couple who cancelled carpet cleaner because of miscarriage' 
The company's terms and conditions ask for 48 hours' notice – but the couple say the circumstances simply did not allow for that. The company's terms and conditions ask for 48 hours' notice – but the couple say the circumstances simply did not allow for that (Photo: SWNS.com) 
However Mr Harbour, who lives in Tavistock, said if he had known the reasons for the cancellation from the outset, this "never would have happened". 
"We probably would have sent her a bunch of flowers," he continued, "like we have done in the past. 
"I understand some people wouldn't want to admit to a company they have had a miscarriage, but had she, the situation would have been completely different. 
"I accept some responsibility, I do, I really do, but we don't deserve what has happened to us. The business is gone and we are having to move house. 
"I've had horrible threats like 'You are worse than Jimmy Savile' and 'I hope you die of cancer'. The 'admin fee' keeps increasing (Photo: SWNS.com) Mr Harbour said: "It's hard to watch something you've spent two years of your life trying to build up and then through one conversation it's blown the business" (Photo: SWNS.com) 
"It's hard to watch something you've spent two years of your life trying to build up and then through one conversation it's blown the business." 
Mr Harbour claims at the time of cancellation, he didn't realise the couple had booked and cancelled the appointment within 24 hours – meaning they couldn't give the required 48 hours notice. He also did not realise Mr and Mrs Coutts were in any distress, he said. 
Mr Harbour said only some of the text messages have been made public - and they don't tell the full story. 
He explained that made it "difficult to enforce" the terms and conditions, but that he "didn't notice" that was the case. Mr Harbour said only some of the text messages have been made public - and they don't tell the full story (Photo: SWNS.com) 
He said: "We asked them politely 'Do you wish to rebook', but then it just spiralled massively and we still hadn't been told at that stage that she had had a miscarriage. 
"There's about 12 messages before she tells us. 
"In our opinion they had already wasted our time by making an appointment they couldn't keep, and contrary to popular belief, at times we are five or six days booked in advance, so appointments are quite important. 
"We live in Tavistock, so if you have a mid-morning appointment [in Plymouth] and you cancel at short notice, we're stuck in town for those hours as there's no point in us driving home, as it is a 40-mile round-trip for us to go back and come back again. Mr Harbour said he has been compared to Jimmy Savile after the incident (Photo: SWNS.com) Read More Mum who spent 16 days with dead baby girl was behaving "totally normally" says expert who claims "some parents spend a MONTH" 
"At that point she told us she had just got out of hospital, but in this business you do become quite hardened to it. 
"We've had people who have said to us 'We don't need the delivery anymore because we've moved house' - so we've sent the invoice through recorded delivery by post and they've signed for it, so they've obviously not moved. 
"We've also had people say they've had a death in the family, then you read on Facebook they haven't." 
Mrs Harbour added: "Losing a baby is tragic, but had we been told from the beginning this was why they couldn't keep the appointment, it wouldn't have been a problem." 
Following the story initially going to the papers, it was reported that police were investigating claims the Harbours told the Coutts "the Harbour told the Coutts "You deserved to lose your baby." The extraordinary Facebook conversation between the Coutts and Clean Carpets Plymouth about a cancelled appointment (Photo: SWNS.com) 
But Mrs Harbour has assured this did not happen. 
"I understand it hasn't been handled very well," she said, " but we didn't ever threaten them. 
Yes, we continued to message her [but] if she was that upset she could have stopped us right at the start and blocked us, rather than giving her phone to [her husband] and letting him continue with it." 
The couple have said since the story was published their whole world has turned upside down. 
Mrs Harbour said: "It's horrible to stand there and have your 35-year-old husband beg you to leave him because he feels that he has let me down. That is how it has affected us – and it's affected our whole family. 
"We don't deserve this. It feels like we've murdered somebody." 
Mr Harbour added: "We've got no idea what we're going to do now. We've got a little bit of savings, but there is even a hate group on Facebook about us. We've lost friends and family because of this." Like us on Facebook
